turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Surprised I agreed to Reed's proposal?

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: I understand the business reasons.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Well, when you're looking at your future, it never hurts to find closure about the past.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: It's been a good two years, Victor... The company's accomplished so much.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Right, of course, the company... But you see, I've come to realize all the accomplishments in the world mean nothing without someone to share them with --

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Uh, Victor, I hope I haven't done something to make you think...

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Sue, I've lived my life unafraid of taking big steps. And this is the biggest step yet. If it helps, think of this as a promotion. A merger of sorts...  Four little words that can change our lives...

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Raising the shields.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: You can't leave them out there.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: What's going on?

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Victor, are you feeling alright?

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Victor, I'm sorry I --

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Just find him.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Victor, your scar --

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I told you, I'm fine. It's you I'm worried about.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: I'm sorry I didn't get a chance to --

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Please, no apologies. I've arranged for your things to be moved to one of my condos. You'll have round-the clock care.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: You said it was urgent.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: It is. There's something we need to talk about. Something I need to ask you...

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Victor, wait, slow down a second. I want you to know I appreciate everything you've done for me, but I just don't --

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Susan. What are you doing?

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: He's working round the clock. But the data needs to be tested, analyzed before --

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Same old Reed. All analysis, no action. Wasn't that the problem with you two?

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: If these molecules aren't stable, they could make us worse, maybe even kill us.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Then why is Reed dragging his feet? Maybe he likes having his prize specimen under glass...  It's ironic, isn't it? You're finally the perfect woman for him... because you're his science project.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Please don't make this personal --

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Oh, I think you already have.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Victor, we can't do anything until the research is ready.

turns.speaker: THE THING
turns.text: 'Scuse me.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I know it can't be easy. Life hasn't changed that much for Reed, Sue and Johnny. At least they can go out in public. But for you? People staring. Whispering behind your back...

turns.speaker: THE THING
turns.text: If you're trying to cheer me up you're doing a helluva job --

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I'm just saying, I know what it's like to lose something you love. To see it slip away, and know it's never coming back.

turns.speaker: THE THING
turns.text: Reed's gonna fix me up --

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: For your sake I hope you're right. I'm sorry if that sounds a little skeptical.

turns.speaker: THE THING
turns.text: Skeptical...?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Brad, can I talk to you a minute?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Arnold. What's happening?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Brad, I really fuckin' hate McDonald's, man. Ever since they started in with the chicken, everything went downhill.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: You want to work at Carl's?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Oh, man, if you could swing something there, I'd do anything for you. I want to work with you guys.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: I can probably get you in there. Just let me talk to Dennis Taylor.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: All right!!

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Were those flowers really for me, Brad?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: How much did they cost?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Don't worry about it.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: What's there to do at the Point? God, Lisa, we've been going together almost two years, and...

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Brad. I don't want to have to use sex as a tool.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Tool? Tool for what? We've been going together almost two years!

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I don't want to talk about it here, Brad.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Man, I don't even want to see those guys from Carl's again.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: If you'd apologize I think Dennis would take you back.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Apologize to that wimp? No way. Fuck Dennis Taylor.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: I'm just glad we're still together, Lisa, because I need you this year.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Look, Brad, I've been trying to think of a way to tell you this. We're almost out of high school, this is our last year. I think we owe it to ourselves to be free, and meet some new people. Then, if we get back together, we'll know it's the right thing.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Something happened to them, mon.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Come on, Spicoli. Why don't you just put your shirts back on? See the sign?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Go ahead. Just make it quick.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Totally.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: It's the first door on your left.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: I can't find it, mon!

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: It's the first door on your left!

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: On the ledge?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: First door on your left!

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: There it is!

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Easy, mon.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Later.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Hamilton, come over here. What is that you've got on?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: This is how I dress all the time.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: But you took off your Captain Kidd uniform.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: I thought I'd take it off for the drive over to IBM. It's kind of uncomfortable.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Come on, Hamilton. You're going over there to represent Captain Kidd Fish and Chips. We have stores all over Southern California. Part of our image, part of our appeal is in our uniforms. You know that!

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: You really want me to put all this stuff back on?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yes. I think so. Show some pride, Hamilton.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Well, I believe you have to fill out a form. There's a pad right around here.

turns.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
turns.text: No. I want my money back right now.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Well, that's not the way it works, really. And you ate most of your food already, too...

turns.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
turns.text: See that sign? It says 100% Money Back Guarantee. Do you know the meaning of the word 'guarantee'? Do they teach you that here? Give me my money back.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: I can't do that. But if you wait a minute...

turns.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
turns.text: Look. Just put your little hand back in the cash register and give me my $2.75 back. Okay?  Please, Brad?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: I'm sorry, sir. Just let me find the forms here.

turns.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
turns.text: I am so tired. I am so tired of dealing with morons. How hard is it to...

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Mister, if you don't shut up, I'm gonna kick 100% of your ass.

turns.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
turns.text: Manager!!

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Hi, Brad.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Sis.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Everyone wants to know where Lisa is. How should I know where Lisa is?  What am I gonna do? Now my little sister goes to the same high school. The party's over.  So who do you have first period?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: U.S. History. Mr. Hand.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Hey-yo.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Mom says to clean up the pool.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Why can't you do it?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Your friends use the pool. Your friends messed it up.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Your friends use the pool too.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: I take out the garbage.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Don't strain yourself.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Brad! Have Mom or Dad seen this?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: They're not home yet.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Brad, what would you say if I asked you to just put these flowers in the trunk of the Cruising Vessel and get rid of them at work?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: I'd say... who the hell is Ron Johnson?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I'll explain everything later.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Thanks for getting rid of those flowers.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Don't worry about it. Who sent the flowers?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: It's just some guy I met at Swenson's. You don't know him.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: I don't care it you tell me or not. I got problems of my own.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Is everything okay at work?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Are you kidding? Work is great. I kill at work. I don't even mind Mom and Dad making me pay rent.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: You're going to break up with Lisa, aren't you?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: I've been doing some thinking. It's my last school year. I'm a single, successful guy. I think I want my freedom.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Why? Because she won't sleep with you?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Where did you hear that?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I'm just guessing.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Well... it's true.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Maybe you just need to give her some time. She's so nice, Brad. Everybody loves Lisa.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Everybody loves Lisa. Everybody loves Lisa. But everybody doesn't have to be her boyfriend.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Hey, Brad. Are you still a virgin?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I don't know. I was just curious.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Maybe yes. Maybe no.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: You are a virgin!

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: I didn't say that.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: But your face did!

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Are you still a virgin?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Maybe yes. Maybe no.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Don't give me that shit! I know you're still a virgin!

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Does Mom know you have company?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: It's just Linda. And Mark from school.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Yeah. This is it. I have some shopping to do.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: See you later.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Thanks a lot, Brad. I really appreciate it.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Since when do you shop at the Flea Market anyway?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Brad. Please don't tell Mom and Dad...

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: You're not going to tell me, are you?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: All right, then. It's your secret.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Any problems?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: No, just a couple of surfers with no shirts on. I took care of it, Dennis.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Did you throw away those fries, Hamilton?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: They were left over from the last shift.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Those were perfectly good fries, Hamilton.  Perfectly good.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: But they weren't mine.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Come on. Clean that counter off Brad. Let's go. Play ball.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Okay, Dennis.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Did you threaten this man or use profanity in any way?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: He insulted me first. He called me a moron.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Did you threaten this customer or use profanity in any way?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: You're fired.

turns.speaker: CURTIS
turns.text: Dad says you have to get up!

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Ugh.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Leave me alone!

turns.speaker: CURTIS
turns.text: Dad says you're late again, you butthole!

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Leave me alone.

turns.speaker: CURTIS
turns.text: Dad says!

turns.speaker: CURTIS
turns.text: Jeff you have company!

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Go away, Curtis. If you can't knock, I can't hear you.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Nice to meet you, Stacy.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Nice to meet you.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Hey! We came over to help you with Math homework!

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Oh, really?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Well, that's exactly why I brought some Wisk for the jacuzzi.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: O-kay, you guys can come swimming. But you have to leave as soon as my Mom gets home. Okay?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I can't wait until I can drive next year. I walk every day. It's such a drag.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Get a ride with somebody.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Sometimes I get a ride with my brother. But he usually works in the mornings, and then drives to school himself.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: What a guy.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: You know Mark Ratner really likes you. You like him?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Mark is a really nice boy...

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Do you have any ice tea?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Sure. Come on in.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I guess the annuals are coming in pretty soon. Are you going to get one?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Aren't you curious to see how your class picture turned out?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: I know what I look like.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Do you want to take a quick swim?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Brad probably has some trunks you can borrow... I'm going to my room to change!

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Pick a suit.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: I don't know. It's getting pretty late...

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Are you really a virgin?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Come on...

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Listen. I feel pretty strange here. Because Mark really likes you, and he's my friend.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: He's my friend, too.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: You're a really good kisser.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: So are you.  Are you shaking?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: No. Are you crazy?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Why don't you take off your clothes, Mike?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: You first.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: How about both of us at the same time?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I want you to know that it's your final decision if we should continue or not.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Let's continue.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Hey, Mike?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: What? Are you all right?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I think we're making a lot of noise.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: I'm sorry. I'm really sorry.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: I think I came. Didn't you feel it?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I guess I did.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Oh. Hi.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I didn't see you this morning.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Look, I'm kind of in a hurry.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I'm in a hurry too. I just thought I could say hi to you.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: What's going on?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Mike, there's something that's been on my mind and I have to tell you about it.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: What? Now?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Why don't you call me up tonight?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Mike. I want you to know that I'm pregnant.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: How do you know it's mine? We only did it once.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I know it's yours.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Take that back.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: All right, I take it back.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: There's only one thing we can do. We've got to get rid of it. We've got to get an abortion.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: We've got to get an abortion?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Yeah. My brother Art got his girlfriend one once.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: It's already planned, Mike. It's going to cost $150 at the Free Clinic.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Doesn't sound free to me.  So you want me to pay for it?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Half. Okay?  Seventy-five dollars. And a ride to the clinic.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Seventy-five dollars, and a ride. Okay.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Mike! You have a mess on C-9!

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: All right. All right. I just cleaned B-8. Give me a break.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Get going.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Do you ever look at those girls who work at Swenson's? They're beautiful. And I have to stand out here and watch them six nights a week.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: You should work for yourself.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: You... are a wuss. Part wimp. Part pussy.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: What do you mean -- wuss? This girl is my exact type. It's her. Definitely her.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: It's definitely your mama.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Damone, you gotta listen to me.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: All right... where did you see her?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: She's in my biology class.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Did you get her number?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Did you get her name?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: No. It's too soon.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: It's never too soon! Girls decide how far to let you go in the first five minutes.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Well, what do you want me to do? Go up to this strange girl in my biology class and say, 'Hello! I'd like you to take your clothes off and jump on me?'

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: I would. Yeah.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: I can see it all now. This is going to be just like the girl you fell in love with at Fotomat this summer. You bought forty bucks of fuckin' film and you never even talked to her.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: You tell me, Mike. What do I do?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Okay. Okay.  Here's what you do.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Don't talk to her. Let her know. Use your face. Use your body. Use everything. This is what I do. I just sent out the vibe and I have personally found that... girls do respond. Something happens.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Of course something happens. You put the vibe out to thirty million chicks, you know something's gonna happen.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: That's the idea, Rat. That's The Attitude.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: The Attitude? The Attitude dictates that you don't care if she comes, stays, lays or prays. Whatever happens, your toes are still tappin'. When you are the cruelest and the coolest... then you have The Attitude.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: The business is changing, Rat. I'll tell you, these kids today... they don't even listen to Aerosmith.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: I hear they all dress like that at Lincoln now.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: There used to be three or four of those guys. Now we see 'em every time we come to the mall.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Hey, Rat.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Ace the jacket.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Knock it off, Damone. I need real help.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: What do you mean? Men have died trying to obtain this information. I will give it to you for free.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Okay. Tell me. What's the Five Point Plan?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: All right. Pay attention.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: And that is how you talk to a girl, Rat. Voila. You can't miss.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: I think I've got it. Once I get going, I'll be okay. But... how do I get started? I mean, I hardly know her.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: You wuss. It's no problem. One person says something to the other and that's how it starts...

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Yo.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Damone. It's Mark.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Mark. What happened to your date?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: It's happening right now. I'm here at the Atlantis. Everything's fine except... I left my wallet at home.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Did you go home and get it?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: No. It's too late. The food is coming and everything. Damone, I've got to ask you this favor, and I'll never ask you for anything again in this lifetime or any other. Will you please borrow your mom's car, go by my house, get my wallet, and meet me back here?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Damone, are you there?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: I'm really pretty busy...

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Hey, Mark. Is that you?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Damone! You come here?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: I come for the seafood. It's great! Hey... you know what, Mark? I found your wallet the other day. You want it back?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Wow. I've been looking for that thing! Hey, Damone, have you met Stacy Hamilton? Stacy, this is Mike Damone.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Well, I've gotta be running.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Okay. See ya.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Poor guy.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Really.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: No. I don't think so. Not right now.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Chicken!

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: If you ask me, she's pretty aggressive. You understand what I'm saying?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: No Damone. I don't understand.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: She wasn't really your girlfriend anyway.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Hey fuck you Damone. There's a lot of girls out there and you mess around with Stacy. What have you got to prove?

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Jesus. I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: I always stick up for you. Whenever people say 'Aw, that Damone is a loudmouth' -- and they say that a lot -- I say 'You just don't know Damone.' When someone says you're an idiot, I tell them 'Damone's not an idiot. You just don't know him.' Well, you know, Damone, maybe they do know you pretty good. And I'm just finding out.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Fine. Get lost.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: You're losing it, Damone.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: You're crazy. Those girls love me.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: The Attitude, Damone, is only good until you meet the right girl.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Whatever you say, Rat.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: And... you can only tell it's the right girl if you're sensitive.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Sensitive -- what is that?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Sensitive is when you can tell how people feel without asking.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: So what makes you so sensitive?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Well, for one, I read. I don't watch as much television as you. I'm trying to feel things more. I'm learning a lot about people.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: What do you read? What's the last book you read?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Lust For Life. It's the story of Vincent Van Gough.

turns.speaker: DAMONE
turns.text: Yeah, well, I saw the movie. That must mean I'm sensitive too.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: It's a way, Damone. It's a vibe. I put it out, and I have personally found that girls do respond.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Are you Linda Barrett?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: I'm Carrie Frazier from Toys 'R Us. Judy Hinton from May Company told me I could ask you something.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: All right, what you want to do is go to the Free Clinic and tell the doctor that you have sex regularly -- several times a week -- and that you need Nornel One Plus Fifty's.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: And they don't call my parents?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Not if you're over sixteen.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Okay. Thanks a lot, Linda.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: And don't let them talk you into a diaphragm either.

turns.speaker: GRIFFIN
turns.text: How've you been?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Outrageous, Merv. Nice to be here. I feel great.

turns.speaker: GRIFFIN
turns.text: I was going to say... your eyes look a little red.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: I've been swimming, Merv.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Seriously, Merv, everything is great. I was thinking about picking up some hash this weekend, maybe going up to the mountains.

turns.speaker: GRIFFIN
turns.text: I wanted to talk a little bit about school, if I could...

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: School.  School is no problem. All you have to do is go to get the grades. And if you know something, all you have to do is go about half the time.

turns.speaker: GRIFFIN
turns.text: How often do you go?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: I don't go at all.

turns.speaker: GRIFFIN
turns.text: I hear you brought a film clip with you. Do you want to set it up for us?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Well, it pretty much speaks for itself. Peter, you want to run with it?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Merv, this is the action down at Sunset Cliffs at about six in the morning.

turns.speaker: GRIFFIN
turns.text: Fascinating.

turns.speaker: GRIFFIN
turns.text: Who's that?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: That's me, Merv.

turns.speaker: GRIFFIN
turns.text: Are you going to ride that wave?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Totally.

turns.speaker: GRIFFIN
turns.text: What's going through your mind right here, Jeff? The danger of it all?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Merv, I'm thinking... I've only got about four good hours of surfing left before these little clowns from junior high start showing up with their boogie boards.

turns.speaker: L.C.
turns.text: Hey, slow down. This is my brother's car.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: I thought he was out of town.

turns.speaker: L.C.
turns.text: He is.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Then don't hassle it.

turns.speaker: L.C.
turns.text: Seen the new Playboy?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Naw. Any good?

turns.speaker: L.C.
turns.text: Suzanne Somers' tits.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: L.C.
turns.text: I like sex.
